text.content: Click a Lesson or Activity to learn more about Brain Development.

The brain rapidly forms new connections; however, many of these connections are not necessary. To increase brain efficiency, connections that are not used are pruned.

In this video clip, Dr. Elizabeth Nelson explains more about pruning and why it is essential for development.

We've now explored how the brain grows and how it prunes itself so that only the necessary circuits in the brain remain. Here is a review of what we've learned so far.

Brain development:

  • Happens rapidly in the first 3â€“5 years of life
  • Is part nature and part nurture
  • Involves creating new circuts based on already-established ones
  • Continues to create and build on neural networks throughout the life span

audio.transcript: The brain rapidly forms new connections; however, many of these connections are not necessary. To increase brain efficiency, connections that are not used are pruned. Because there are so many connections, there is a great deal of pruning in the first 3 years. In this video clip, Dr. Elizabeth Nelson explains more about pruning and why it is essential for development.

We've now explored how the brain grows and how it prunes itself so that only the necessary circuits in the brain remain. Here is a review of what we've learned so far. Brain development happens rapidly in the first 3-5 years of life, is part nature and part nurture, involves creating new circuits based on already-established ones, and continues to create and build on neural networks throughout the life span.
